item.title: Loss of Oxygen in Lakes and Oceans a Major Threat to Ecosystems, Society, and Planet
item.description: Oxygen is a fundamental requirement of life, and the loss of oxygen in water, referred to as aquatic deoxygenation, is a threat to life at all levels. In fact, in research recently published in Nature Ecology and Evolution, Rensselaer’s Associate Professor Kevin Rose, Ph.D. and his collaborators describe how ongoing deoxygenation presents a major threat to the stability of the planet as a whole.
item.author: Community

item.title: Rensselaer Researcher Draws Insights from COVID-19 to Inform Improved Health Care in Times of Crisis
item.description: Among the many challenges COVID-19 presented, disruptions in health care were among the most impactful; the large-scale pandemic resulted in millions of hospitalizations and deaths in the United States alone, and also affected many routine medical services. In research recently published in Nature Medicine, Rensselaer’s Jianxi Gao, Ph.D., associate professor of computer science, and his team measured our health care system’s resilience and adaptability to disruptions caused by COVID-19.
item.author: Community

item.title: RPI hosts NORDTECH summit addressing microchip worker shortage
item.description: If you’re into the humanities, you may be wondering what microchips — aka semiconductors — do. They’re the basic building blocks for modern technologies like ATMs, planes, and AI, and there’s a worker shortage in that industry, so RPI is trying to bridge that gap through a NORDTECH program.
item.author: Community

item.title: “Leaders in Action” Conversation to be Held with Trustee Dr. John Capek
item.description: Date: Thursday, August 1, 2024 4:00 PM - 6:00 PM - During this session, hosted by Prof. Azita Hirsa, Trustee John Capek B.S. ’83, M.E. ’84, M.E. ’85, MBA ’87, Ph.D. ’88, retired Executive Vice President at Abbott Ventures, a global healthcare company, will discuss the intersection of business, entrepreneurship, and science and engineering. Participants will have the opportunity to ask questions related to the topic. Refreshments will be served following the session.

item.title: Joint ECSE/CBIS Seminar on Life Science Automation Scheduled for July 29
item.description: Date: Monday, July 29, 2024 10:30 AM - 11:30 AM - Professors Kerstin Thurow and Heidi Fleischer — from the Center for Life Science Automation (Celisca) at the University of Rostock, Germany — will jointly present a seminar focusing on life science automation research in Celisca.

item.title: Summer Outdoor Program Series Continues with Day Hike at Moxham Mountain
item.description: Date: Wednesday, July 31, 2024 8:00 AM - 3:00 PM - Students are invited to join this daytime hiking trip on Moxham Mountain, located near the town of Minerva, New York! The trip, which is approximately five miles round-trip and should take about three hours, is limited to ten participants and registration is required; please look for information and registration on the Muller Center’s Instagram page, or contact Will Weinert if you have questions.

item.title: Student Fall ’24/Spring ’25 Parking Permits Available as of August 1
item.description: Student parking permits for the Fall ’24/Spring ’25 semesters will be available for sale beginning Thursday, August 1. Please note that first-year students are not allowed to have a vehicle on campus, and all other students must register and have a valid permit before parking on campus. For additional information, please contact the Parking office by phone at (518) 276-6616 or via email.

item.title: OUE Announces ChatGPT/AI Tools Informal Community Space
item.description:
The Office of Undergraduate Education is pleased to announce that an informal community Webex space has been created to focus directly on AI tools being used in the classroom, and is available to share, collaborate, and brainstorm on this topic. Faculty, staff, or graduate TAs who would like to join this space should email Maureen Fodera.
